_accidents.CF_Other: Contractor's harness lanyard snagged on purge valve and broke it off

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Don Miguel Mexican Foods of Dallas, Texas prepares foods which are cooked and frozen for storage and shipment to retail vendors.   One of the refrigerants used is anhydrous ammonia.  The ammonia refrigeration system includes two machinery rooms for flash freezers and storage areas.  The facility has been in operation since 1998 and in 2006 the plant expansion resulted in having more than 10,000 lbs ammonia in the processes.     



The persons working at the plant consist of employees and a significant number of contract employees.   A sanitation firm provides approximately 200 contract employees.  Furthermore, typically 100 to 200 contract employees are used in food processing areas.    



The ammonia is contained in a closed loop system; it is designed to remain inside the piping and vessels in our facility.  Ammonia as contained in equipment in the facility is compressed, condensed and evaporated to remove heat from within the facility to maintain safe storage areas and remove heat from the products being handled.  We believe that ammonia provides the safest and most efficient cooling choice for our operation. 



Ammonia is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical and it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal, State, and local laws, statutes, codes, rules, and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.



A. Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies 



An accidental release prevention program has been in place since the facility increased the ammonia on site above the 10,000 lb threshold. The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia R

efrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, and is in compliance with State and local codes.  This food processing facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable State and local codes and regulations.



We take many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system. These precautions include safety controls (alarms and automatic shutdown devices) which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions like pressure increases that could cause a system failure. We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel, and emergency response procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets. 



The Manager of Plant Engineering is responsible for the management of these ammonia safety programs. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled 



Ammonia is the only substance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations handled at this facility. 



C. Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program 



The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements: 



? Employee Participation Program: 

The Plant has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.   

? Process Safety Information: 

Ammonia refrigeration equipment manuals and plant design technical specifications including piping diagrams are on file.  

? Process Hazard Analysis: 

A process hazard analysis (PHA) re-validation was conducted in December 2015 and another PHA re-validation is schedule for December 20

20.   A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of control system failures.  

? Operating Procedures: 

Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  These SOPs were converted to the IIAR format in 2015.  

? Training Program: 

An operator training program is designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel.  

? Contractor Safety Program: 

Contractors that are used to work on or adjacent to the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.  

? Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures: 

See comments under Management of Change  

? Mechanical Integrity Program: 

The Plant has a program for replacement of all Safety Relief Valves on a 5 year interval as recommended by IIAR.  We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the system.  

? Hot Work Permit Procedures: 

The plant has implemented a Hot Work permit program including training.  

? Management of Change Procedures: 

For projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to ensure that system changes or expansions are safe and that t

he changes are consistent with the engineering design and in condition to be operated prior to startup.  

? Incident Investigation Procedures: 

An incident investigation program is in place at the plant to review incidents and implement any identified improvement(s) to reduce future potential for new incidents to occur.  

? Compliance Audit Procedures: 

At least every three years a full program audit is conducted.  



D. Five-Year Accident History 



Don Miguel Foods has experienced two accidents in the past 5 years.  None of these accidents resulted in a death, injury, or significant property damage on site or any off-site consequences.  The details of these accidents can be found in the accident history section.

 

E. Description of the Emergency Response Program 



An emergency response program has been implemented at the facility. This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures. The program has been coordinated with local fire department officials. 



The emergency response program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility emergency response plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements.  The emergency response plan has been discussed with the Dallas Fire Department and other agencies involved with response.  Representatives of the Dallas Fire Department visit this plant on an annual basis.  



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan and will evacuate or shelter in place if a significant release occurs.



F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



Identification of opportunities and changes to improve safety is part of the culture of this plant.



?Don Miguel Foods has recently completed a three phase refrigeration

system upgrade which has provided modernized equipment and controls.  New standard operating procedures and training procedures have been developed for this system.  No future changes are currently planned.
